author: potuz
content: I do not think this has anything to do with PBS: the forkchoice rule already has mechanisms to prevent arbitrary forking of some validators.  As for crLists, the proposer is supposed to send them with his block so that it's onchain that the builder has to either include those transactions or prove his block was full.  I don't understand much of game theory, but it looks to me that proposers colluding with builders is a winning game

author: sky.cactus
content: PBS doesn't address reorg type attacks at the protocol layer.  They still would need to be addressed at the social layer.

author: sky.cactus
content: The fundamental problem with reorg attacks is that while all individuals may agree that censorship is occurring with very high probability (because they are individually witnessing it), it is very very difficult to come to agreement on when exactly that censorship started and when exactly the correct time to take action is.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is similar to a country where all of the individuals know the government is corrupt, yet they do not revolt because it is incredibly difficult to coordinate a revolt such that everyone revolts at the exact same time, and revolting at different times will result in losing the revolt.
